title: Antoine Hey
text:
Antoine Hey (born 19 September 1970) is a German <a href="Association%20football">football</a> coach and former professional player. He has been manager of <a href="Myanmar%20national%20football%20team">Myanmar</a> since October 2019.
He spent most of his playing career in the top two <a href="German%20football%20league%20system">divisions of German football</a>, and went on to manage a number of national teams.
Club career.
Hey played mainly for <a href="Fortuna%20D%C3%BCsseldorf">Fortuna Düsseldorf</a> and <a href="FC%20Schalke%2004">Schalke 04</a> in Germany, as well as <a href="Tennis%20Borussia%20Berlin">Tennis Borussia Berlin</a>, <a href="SC%20Fortuna%20K%C3%B6ln">Fortuna Köln</a>, <a href="VfL%20Osnabr%C3%BCck">VfL Osnabrück</a>, <a href="Anorthosis%20Famagusta">Anorthosis Famagusta</a> and <a href="VfR%20Neum%C3%BCnster">VfR Neumünster</a>.
Managerial career.
Hey began his management career in Germany with <a href="VfR%20Neum%C3%BCnster">VfR Neumünster</a> before moving to Africa to manage <a href="Lesotho%20national%20football%20team">Lesotho</a>. Hey was also manager of <a href="Gambia%20national%20football%20team">Gambia</a> from September 2006 until March 2007. His spell with Gambia was marred by concerns over money. He was appointed manager of <a href="Liberia%20national%20football%20team">Liberia</a> in February 2008. In February 2009, he was appointed coach of the <a href="Kenya%20national%20football%20team">Kenyan national team</a>. After disputes with the governing body over team selection, Hey walked out on Kenya's national team shortly before the final <a href="2010%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20-%20CAF%20Third%20Round">World Cup qualifier</a> against <a href="Nigeria%20national%20football%20team">Nigeria</a>.
Later on, he worked as a Technical Director for the <a href="Libyan%20Football%20Federation">Libyan Football Federation</a> from 2010 until 2014, and in the same role for the <a href="Bahrain%20Football%20Association">Bahrain Football Association</a> from 2015 until 2016. In November 2016, Hey returned to management with Sudanese club <a href="Al-Merrikh%20SC">Al-Merrikh</a>, but he was sacked in January 2017 due to poor results, directly after the draw with <a href="AS%20Ali%20Sabieh%20Djibouti%20T%C3%A9l%C3%A9com">ASAS Djibouti Télécom</a> in the <a href="2017%20UAFA%20Club%20Championship">2017 UAFA Club Championship</a>.
In February 2017 he was one of a number of managers on the shortlist for the vacant <a href="Rwanda%20national%20football%20team">Rwanda national team</a> manager role. He was appointed manager of <a href="Rwanda%20national%20football%20team">the Rwanda national team</a> in March 2017. He asked to quit in January 2018.
In May 2018, he was appointed in a dual role as manager of <a href="Myanmar%20national%20football%20team">Myanmar</a> and its <a href="Myanmar%20national%20under-23%20football%20team">under-23 team</a> on a one-and-half-year deal. In the <a href="2018%20AFF%20Championship">2018 AFF Championship</a>, Myanmar drew with Vietnam under controversial circumstances. Hey was criticized for his aggressive behaviour in this match towards the Vietnamese players and their manager <a href="Park%20Hang-seo">Park Hang-seo</a>. He was sacked in December 2018. He returned to Myanmar in October 2019.
Personal life.
His father, <a href="Jonny%20Hey">Jonny Hey</a>, was also a professional footballer, playing for MSV Duisburg, Arminia Bielefeld, Grasshoppers Zürich and Fortuna Köln between 1972 and 1980.
